titleproper.value:
Guide to the Arthur H. Landis Papers
                    <num>ALBA.066</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Wendy Scheir, June 2004, Gail Malmgreen, 2011

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-28T16:29-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
Arthur H. Landis (1917-1986) was a U.S. volunteer in the Spanish Civil War. Arriving in Spain in April 1937, he first served as a scout, a typographer, and an artillery spotter with the (Canadian) MacKenzie-Papineau Battalion, and later served with the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. In 1967, Landis wrote 
                <title render="italic">The Abraham Lincoln Brigade</title>about U.S. volunteers in the Spanish Civil War, and later published 
                <title render="italic">Spain! The Unfinished Revolution</title>, about the political complexities of the war. The Arthur H. Landis Papers contain correspondence and writings produced between 1960 and 1985; family papers, 1910-1940, and miscellaneous ephemera and artifacts relating to Landis's service in Spain.

p.value:
Published citations should take the following form: 
                <lb/>
                <lb/>Identification of item, date; Collection name; Collection number; box number; folder number; 
                <lb/>Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives 
                <lb/>Elmer Holmes Bobst Library 
                <lb/>70 Washington Square South 
                <lb/>New York, NY 10012, New York University Libraries.
Landis died of bone cancer in January 1986 in Los Angeles.

<emph render="bold">Series V: Artifacts/Ephemera</emph> consists of two Spanish Civil War commemorative medals awarded to Landis in the 1960s; a pocket mileage converter; shoe taps and a banjo string, mementos kept by Alice Fries; and sheet music with vaudeville songs, including handwritten scores composed by Richard Yaryan.

corpname.value: Veterans of the Abraham Lincoln Brigade. Historical Commission.
